label: 東遊
本: A Tale of Flowering Fortunes:  Annals of Japanese Aristocratic Life in the Heian Period (Volumes One and Two) . Stanford University Press . 1980
説明文: [Also azuma-mai (東舞, Eastern dancing")] [Sacred music and dancing presented at festivals.] An azuma-asobi program usually required the services of one or more singers, four or six dancers, and a small orchestra consisting of a Japanese zither (wagon, a six-stringed koto), a flute (komabue), and oboe (hichiriki), and pair of clappers (shakubyōshi).  The performers were usually members of the [Court] Bodyguards who came from musical families.  A full program consisted of five sections:  two introductory songs (icni no uta, ni no uta); a first dance, "Suruga-mai," accompanied by songs with a strong folk flavor; a shorter second dance, "Motomeko," with more formal lyrics; and closing music (kataoroshi), during which the dancers retired (p. 404). [和琴、高麗笛、篳篥、笏拍子、一歌、二歌、駿河舞、求子舞、加太於呂志] "
